[split] One step on the road to get pants publishing in the birdcage is to add provides() clauses to the BUILD files.  This is the result of running a script, that mines the POM files for artifacts to publish.  Maven and pants don't correspond 1:1, however, so this may result in some provides() being put on objects that won't ever publish, and some provides() missing on things that do.  This should serve as a first cut, that we might tweak in subsequent RBs.

[split] The new version of pants, released this morning, does A Very Bad Thing (TM) when encountering META-INF/services files that don't end a newline. As a workaround, this change fixes the problematic files in the repo. We will then make pants more tolerant of files that don't have a proper line ending.

[split] Upgrade pants. This RB represents 127 commits to a shared branch to get birdcage upgraded to run on a modern (only several hours old at the moment) OSS pants. [split] fix a race condition on closing in DefaultServer Adserver was having a problem where hitting /quitquitquit would not shutdown their service. Analysis shows that the service would close the listening socket, but a certain number of open connections would not be closed. Reading the code, I discovered a race condition in the way DefaultServer is closed, and I suspect this is the cause.

[split] remove use of deprecated generated ostrich ThriftServer The generated ostrich-based ThriftServer class that scrooge generates is deprecated and going away soon.  Short-term, you can use scrooge-ostrich's OstrichThriftServer for the same functionality, although longer terms, all projects should be switching to twitter-server.  This review removes the use of the generated ThriftServer for all projects in the birdcage that are using the current version of scrooge.  Some projects unnecessarily include the "--ostrich" in their pom, and those resulted in trivial pom changes.  For projects actually using the generated ThriftServer, I've switched you over to the non-generated OstrichThriftServer.

[split] Finagle Tracer: Improve performance This is an attempt to speed up tracing when a trace is unsampled.  This is done by delaying most expensive operations until after checking that a trace will be sampled. Also I try to limit the amount of times this check is done by adding a Trace.isActivelyTracing method and gating expensive operations with it. I had to change some of the unit tests to reflect this new behavior, but most of the backwards-compatibility is preserved.

[split] Performance improvement for finagle-zipkin finagle-zipkin's DeadlineSpanMap logs incomplete spans after a certain deadline.  However, it was not canceling the deadline task if the span completed naturally.  Johan Harjono reported this was causing some GC pressure by keeping every closure around for 2 minutes.

[split] - Bump version of scrooge-runtime to 3.1.2-SNAPSHOT. It is backward compatible and can be a drop in replacement of previous versions (Thanks to Jeremy Cloud). This means all current scrooge projects are able to, and should, use the same runtime version. Each project can upgrade to scrooge 3 code generator individually. Details at: go/ScroogeThrift - For projects on scrooge-runtime HEAD version (2.4.1-SNAPSHOT), they are upgraded to 3.1.2-SNAPSHOT - For projects that use scrooge-maven-plugin, they need to upgrade the plugin to scrooge-maven-plugin_2.9.2-3.1.1, the version that works with scrooge-runtime 3.1.1 and later.

[split]  Improve zipkin trace sampling. This is a patch to resolve an issue with trace_id's colliding in zipkin. It is done by giving each instance a random salt at startup, and the subset of sampled traces is based on that salt.  This ensures full 64-bit coverage of traceIds in a multi-host deployment like tfe.

[split]  Future.Nil Like Future.None, Future.Nil can be used anytime you need a Future[Seq[_]] with an empty sequence.  Using this rather than always creating a new Future can save a tiny bit on garbage generation, plus makes the code marginally easier to read.  I've done a search-and-replace in a few select projects to use the new constant.

[split]  Replication Cache Client A base cache replication client which manages a list of underlying cache client objects, and provides replication operations returning ReplicationStatus object aggregates the underlying replicas consistency. [split] collection.Set => collection.immutable.Set per #116 immutable.Set is the default Set, so if it's described as collection.Set, you can't just say the return value of something that returns a client.sMembers is a Future[Set[ChannelBuffer]], it's a Future[scala.collection.Set[ChannelBuffer]].  There is also no reason to create ambiguity as to whether it's immutable or not, because it makes much more sense for the api to return an immutable version.

[split] Add flags field to thrift header in finagle-thrift Ruby gem. Finagle has added a flags field in the headers. This is currently only used to pass through a debug flag. If set, that flag ensures that the Zipkin back end will skip sampling and store that trace. This is useful for developers who can then make sure the trace for a particular request is stored.

[split] The timers were needlessly convoluted. I think this fixes most of it. Most of the simplification comes from: avoiding the double indirection of netty/util timers, and conflating a few things into a "managed timer".

[split] Add a debug flag developers can use to make sure we pass all samplers. The Macaw team and others have requested that we add a debug flag to the tracing component. This would ensure that the trace with the flag set passes all of the sampling stages (including the one in the Zipkin collector, by passing the flag in the Span). To do this right now the process is pretty involved and this would simplify it greatly. Should be backwards compatible with services that don't know about the debug flag.

[split] This branch adds an i64 bit field to the thrift request header struct and as a http header. It will initially be used just by the debug flag but one could imagine it being used by a few other things, for example it's worth noting that the sampled flag could be folded into this field at a later date. It ought to be more future proof than an individual boolean as per discussion with Marius.

[split] Cluster.map needs to ensure mapping from T to U is 1-1. If the mapping function creates a new instantiation each time, it maps the same value of T to different objects. This is associated with bug CSL-79. Zookeeper sees an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when processing Cluster.Rem(factory), because it is removing a factory that does not exist in the cluster. The factory is created by ClientBuilder.hostToServiceFactory function, and a different instance is created when Cluster.Rem is sent.
